job_title: Crew Member/Grill Cook in Memphis, TN
pros: There is nothing positive to say
cons: This place sucks so bad omg just dont

pros:
Discount on food/getting it for free. 
Learning about how to do schedules, how to interview and how to deal with customers, this job also naturally make you do a lot of multi tasking.

One thing with McDonald’s they are EXTREMELY flexible especially if you’ve been here for a very long time.
cons:
Demands don’t meet pay.
The owners don’t care about employees safety they more care about the customers satisfaction than our own safety. Customers being extremely violent in normalized to the point where if an employee were to be assaulted and me as a shift manger report to my higher managers they say it’s “apart of customer service”.

FYI : there are different type of managers, the ladder of the Management team starts from shift manager (which is my position) , then there’s assistant manager , then second assistant manager, then there’s general manager , then we have the supervisor and etc. 
the positions matter the more higher you move up the more you get paid and the more accountability you have on things. Shift managers are usually part timers or youths taking time off from school (me) . Unless your in love with McDonald’s and plan to make your way up the ladder it doesn’t make sense nor isn’t worth the stress. I make 17.50, 2 dollars more than our now minimum wage which is 15 dollars. not worth the stress nor the disrespect. 

Oh and they play favourites, allow people to do one thing but not allow others to that same thing. Time to time I complain about this and nothing gets done, there all talk no play.

review_title: I worked at a McDonald's in my teens. It was... enlightening.
pros:
As far as entry-level jobs go, I think working in fast food might be one of the best ways to get some really quick experience in how the world REALLY works. Probably a good place to get your kids to work if they start complaining about your rules. I know I learned my lesson.
Training was effective, though operating a grill or commercial bun warmer is not exactly a complicated task to begin with.
My manager at this particular sure was nice. I recall having multiple pleasant interactions with her under circumstances I cannot accurately recall.
cons: this particular McDonald's store had an owner (at least I think it was the owner? it's been a really long time. I want to say the name was Steve) that really did not seem to like me. While I can't entirely blame him in hindsight, given how I was as a teen, I seem to recall him cutting my hours rather than confronting me about whatever issue he had with me (and again, having an issue would've been fine on its own), which still does not sit well with me. I could be misremembering, but... yeah that's the biggest problem I have with my experience there.

pros: - Food Discounts - When you have to dig in the trash, they give gloves
cons: Customers at McDonalds get off on treating you badly. Often it was the customers yelling at me and not the managers. Then the managers would hide in the office and leave new employees alone at the front.

pros: Stable job, respected training,good stepping stone or starting point.
cons: The expectation is managers have to be employees and manage at the same time. You have people over top of you that are kinda disconnected. They remember the working environment from 20 plus years ago and think that the work force is still the same. They focus on numbers and not people. Everything is about a time or percent. There is no investment on training team members. You are expected to still hit that labor percent which forces people to be thrown into it rather than trained. New things are always added to your plate without any give. No work life balance. You can't have a weekend off. Even on vacation someone is calling you about something.

review_title: Would Rather Work Table or Grill than Deal with Customers
pros: Coworkers. If you ever have to work peak meal times or are understaffed, you will eventually feel like you have gone through a food war and will eventually realize that laughing is the best way to deal with the stress. Corporate provides tuition assistance for workers to further their education, which is helpful.
cons: Had life threatened twice as a group via phone death threats from customers relayed via management. Was coughed on by a customer purposefully in the drive-thru at the beginning of COVID lockdowns and before our sneeze guard went up and masks were readily available/required. Had large drinks thrown next to my head by people I didn't know as a prank? Customers taking their bad moods/days out on workers. Ended up with back issues due to having to often stand in place like a tree. People not cutting off their extremely loud motors when placing an order in drive-thru.

review_title: McDonalds, the good the bad the ugly
pros:
If you are fortunate enough to constantly move up then it can be decent pay for the food industry 

great for business training if you move up and there Business programs are reconsigned in my experience by  many other employers aside from McDonald's  

forged some great friendships with most of the  managers/general managers that really wanted you to succeed,cared about people and where otherwise decent human souls 

met great friendly people,
cons:
-some stores have toxic work environment's
-unless decently renovated some stores have really old equipment and don't want to spend money / new equipment designed to make it easier for everyone
-they don't offer incentives like a night shift differential  
-sometimes it feels like to much emphasis on trying to be fast at the expense of the customers and employee's alike
-unless its a solid store , too many people call in sick, take advantage ,   
-favoritism and to much politics 
-all kinds of guests and in the rougher area stores expect to deal with crack heads,  to many people look down on McDonald's, defiantly not a fan of getting stabbed over a cheese burger

pros:
gives you tough skin, makes you learn how to multitask and learn a lot/gain lots of experience. Overall a good ladder/stepping stone into the work field. Can learn kitchen, take orders, process, stocking, cafe, etc. and meet lots of new people. Preferred night shifts as they were more of people my age and the managers were better and less selfish/chill.

If you make a mistake, as long as its not regularly its not taken to heart or personal (some of my managers reassured the staff it was okay but some of the older ones might get mad).

Somewhat flexible hours.
cons:
Not good long term, managers can be unprofessional and can tire you out. 

Only good for a few months. Sometimes, it may be slightly raining and they would still park cars and get you to run it out or not follow covid safety procedures.

They are VERY VERY obsessed with drive thru timers and will get blamed if your slow. Not a Job for sensitive people.

Only 50% if your working on that shift on a specific menu and 10% outside. Wished there was more.

pros: You can get free food, and if you are one of the closing people, you can get all the leftovers! Although, you can get a free meal during your break for any fast food you work at. But, since it's an entry level job, it actually teaches you a lot about the work force and how to prepare for it and the pay over in my area is okay.
cons: Extremely fast pace, like if you don't have the food ready with you, be prepared to park the car. You also have to remember customers want their food fast too, as well as correct. This fast pace environment leads to stressed out workers and stressed out managers which results in high tension. No one is happy during a rush hour unless you have your good buds with you to help lift up your spirits, but good luck if your manager doesn't like it.
